instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with a 0.000 diode measurement on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. I've removed <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> to eliminate some variables. Nothing heats up when I send power through the circuit. I sent around 3amps at 1V for at least 5 minutes. Nothing was heating up. Heatsink was removed.
I've run flux under the CPU and heated it up for an extensive amount of time. After that I did another ultrasonic cleaning. No change. Any ideas what this might be?

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message: Any history?? Resistance on L7310 and L7320 to GND?? Where are you applying voltage after remove <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR>??

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message:
I don't know the history on this one. It was a spill but I'm not seeing any signs of it. I connected my leads to <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>.
L7310 Resistance to Ground: 305Ω
L7320 Resistance to Ground: 328Ω

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message: Seems nothing wrong there, put back resistors and measure again.....

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message: I'm curious what you're thinking is with this. I put the them back on and the short measures 0.000 drop to ground across both resistors.

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message: According to the data you provide the processor is burned, but I do not see a reason to be true if there are no traces of water damage or short on power rail (<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>)

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message: What is Ohmic resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. If it <1 then probably shorted CPU.

threads.title: Measuring dead short on CPU VCORE on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Any hope?
threads.message:
Yeah, the board was definitely hit by liquid. There just aren't any visible signs. Someone else here cleaned it with an ultrasonic before I got to it.

Thanks for the input, I was assuming the CPU was fried but was just hoping there might be some outside chance it was something else.
